An excellent thread of discussion here with some very good observations by
all.

From what I've seen, when you design a test you are operating within the
constraints of an iron triangle whose vertices are coverage, control and
granularity.

Coverage is a measure of the functionality that the test proves to work or
not work.
Control is a measure of accuracy, or your ability to determine or influence
what is covered.
Granularity is the level at which you are testing.

So you find black-box testing from the end-user interface at one end of the
spectrum, with a high degree of coverage, but little control and
granularity. Way at the other end of the spectrum, you test methods (or
statements if you want to really go far), in which you have a high degree of
control and granularity but low coverage.

Now add effort to the mix, which tends to push you to maximize coverage per
unit of effort expended creating the test. This is what makes UI
record/playback tools so compelling (if you forget their other limitations).

So one of the reasons we unit test must be to increase our control over what
is tested. Discovering defects early is one of the other main reasons, but
is not relevant to this discussion. Given this, it seems reasonable that on
occasion, we might want to test a private method, assuming that it does not
meet the criteria for being refactored, but in general we should keep in
mind the necessity to minimize effort while satisfying functionality
coverage objectives.

> Hi Jim,
>
>
> snip
> > Undoubtably that's true. But then if we are accepting that testing
> > public/friendly/protected methods adecuately test these methods, why not
> go
> > one step beyond and say that black box testing is all we need?
> It seems to
> > me that testing private methods is as useful and valid as testing
> > non-private ones, just at a different level of granularity.
> >
> snip
>
>     yes, you may test private methods. But that is not what actually is
> intended by unit testing. The idea is to write tests for the unit and
> thereby to specify what this unit is capable of. The idea of unit
> testing is
> not testing per se. The cool thing is that you finish writing your unit,
> when your tests pass, which cuts down time in testing and implementation.
>
>     Later unit testing (the TestAll called when integrating) helps us
> finding out misbehaving units after refactoring or other code changes.
>
>     I know that this aproach is not based on mathematical
> abductions but on
> experience. Thus I don't want to make a religion out of it, but just do it
> as good habbit.
> And I don't believe that there is a proof, that testing is more and more
> efficiant, the more granular you test. Well, you could test every line of
> code.
